title: The category of extensible structures
content: The "category of extensible structures" ` ExtStrCat ` is the category of all sets in a universe regarded as extensible structures and the functions between their base sets, see ~ df-estrc . Since we consider only "small categories" (i.e. categories whose objects and morphisms are actually sets and not proper classes), the objects of the category (i.e. the base set of the category regarded as extensible structure) are all sets in a universe ` u `, which can be an arbitrary set, see ~ estrcbas . Generally, we will take ` u ` to be a weak universe or Grothendieck universe, because these sets have closure properties as good as the real thing. If a set is not a real extensible structure, it is regarded as extensible structure with an empty base set. Because of ~ bascnvimaeqv we do not need to restrict the universe to sets which "have a base". The morphisms (or arrows) between two objects, i.e. sets from the universe, are the mappings between their base sets, see ~ estrchomfval , whereas the composition is the ordinary composition of functions, see ~ estrccofval and ~ estrcco . It is shown that the category of extensible structures ` ExtStrCat ` is actually a category, see ~ estrccat with the identity function as identity arrow, see ~ estrcid . In the following, some background information about the category of extensible structures is given, taken from the discussion in Github issue #1507 (see ~ https://github.com/metamath/set.mm/issues/1507 ): At the beginning, the categories of non-unital rings ` RngCat ` and unital rings ` RingCat ` were defined separately (as unordered triples of ordereds pairs, see ~ dfrngc2 and ~ dfringc2 , but with special compositions). With this definitions, however, theorem ~ rngcresringcat could not be proven, because the compositions were not compatible. Unfortunately, no precise definition of the composition within the category of rings could be found in the literature. In section 3.3 EXAMPLES, paragraph (2) of [Adamek] p. 22, however, a definition is given for "Grp", the category of groups: "The following constructs; i.e., categories of structured sets and structure-preserving functions between them (o will always be the _composition of functions_ and id_A will always be the identity function on A): ... (b) Grp with objects all groups and morphisms all homomorphisms between them." Therefore, the compositions should have been harmonized by using the composition of the category of sets ` SetCat `, see ~ df-setc , which is the ordinary composition of functions. Analogously, categories of Rngs (and Rings) could have been shown to be restrictions resp. subcategories of the category of sets. BJ and MC observed, however, that "... ` |``cat ` [cannot be used] to restrict the category Set to Ring, because the homs are different. Although Ring is a concrete category, a hom between rings R and S is a function (Base``R) --> (Base``S) with certain properties, unlike in Set where it is a function R --> S.". Therefore, MC suggested that "we could have an alternative version of the Set category consisting of extensible structures (in U) together with (A Hom B) := (Base``A) --> (Base``B). This category is not isomorphic to Set because different extensible structures can have the same base set, but it is equivalent to Set; the relevant functors are (U``A) = (Base``A), the forgetful functor, and (F``A) = { <. (Base``ndx), A >. }". This led to the current definition of ` ExtStrCat `, see ~ df-estrc . The claimed equivalence is proven by ~ equivestrcsetc . Having a definition of a category of extensible structures, the categories of non-unital and unital rings can be defined as appropriate restrictions of the category of extensible structures, see ~ df-rngc and ~ df-ringc . In the same way, more subcategories could be provided, resulting in the following "inclusion chain" by proving theorems like ~ rngcresringcat , although the morphisms of the shown categories are different ( "->" means "is subcategory of"): ` RingCat ` -> ` RngCat ` -> GrpCat -> MndCat -> MgmCat -> ` ExtStrCat ` According to MC, "If we generalize from subcategories to embeddings, then we can even fit ` SetCat ` into the chain, equivalent to ` ExtStrCat ` at the end." As mentioned before, the equivalence of ` SetCat ` and ` ExtStrCat ` is proven by ~ equivestrcsetc . Furthermore, it can be shown that ` SetCat ` is _embedded_ into ` ExtStrCat `, see ~ embedsetcestrc . Remark: ~ equivestrcsetc as well as ~ embedsetcestrc require that the index of the base set extractor is contained within the considered universe. This is ensured by assuming that the natural numbers are contained within the considered universe: ` _om e. U ` (see ~ wunndx ), but it would be currently sufficient to assume that ` 1 e. U `, because the index value of the base set extractor is hard-coded as ` 1 `, see ~ basendx . Some people, however, feel uncomfortable to say that a ring "is a" group (without mentioning the restriction to the addition, which is usually found in the literature, e.g. the definition of a ring in [Herstein] p. 126: "... Note that so far all we have said is that R is an abelian group under +.". The main argument against a ring being a group is the number of components/slots: usually, a group consists of (exactly!) two components (a base set and an operation), whereas a ring consists of (exactly!) three components (a base set and two operations). According to this "definition", a ring cannot be a group. This is also an (unfortunately informal) argument for the category of rings not being a subcategory of the category of abelian groups in "Categories and Functors", Bodo Pareigis, Academic Press, New York, London, 1970: "A category A is called a subcategory of a category B if Ob(A) C_ Ob(B) and Mor_A(X,Y) C_ Mor_B(X,Y) for all X,Y e. Ob(A), if the composition of morphisms in A coincides with the composition of the same morphisms in B and if the identity of an object in A is also the identity of the same object viewed as an object in B. Then there is a forgetful functor from A to B. We note that Ri [the category of rings] _is not a subcategory_ of Ab [the category of abelian groups]. In fact, Ob(Ri) C_ Ob(Ab) is not true, although every ring can also be regarded as an abelian group. The corresponding abelian groups of two rings may coincide even if the rings do not coincide. The multiplication may be defined differently.". As long as we define Rings, Groups, etc. in a way that ` A e. Ring -> ` ` A e. Grp ` is valid (see ~ ringgrp ) the corresponding categories are in a subcategory relation. If we do not want Rings to be Groups (then the category of rings would not be a subcategory of the category of groups, as observed by Pareigis), we would have to change the definitions of Magmas, Monoids, Groups, Rings etc. to restrict them to have exactly the required number of slots, so that the following holds ` g e. Grp -> g Struct <. ( Base `` ndx ) , ( +g `` ndx ) >. ` ` r e. Ring -> r Struct <. ( Base `` ndx ) , ( +g `` ndx ) , ( .r `` ndx ) >. `

blocks.name: fncnvimaeqv
blocks.content: The inverse images of the universal class ` _V ` under functions on the universal class ` _V ` are the universal class ` _V ` itself. (Proposed by Mario Carneiro, 7-Mar-2020.) (Contributed by AV, 7-Mar-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm fncnvimaeqv(class c0) {
  |- wi(wfn(c0, universe), wceq(cima(ccnv(c0), universe), universe))
} = {
  eqtrd(cima(ccnv(c0), universe), universe, crab(hs0, universe, wcel(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), universe)), wfn(c0, universe))
  fncnvima2(hs0, c0, universe, universe)
  eqrdv(hs1, crab(hs0, universe, wcel(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), universe)), universe, wfn(c0, universe))
  syl6rbbr(wfn(c0, universe), wcel(cv(hs1), crab(hs0, universe, wcel(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), universe))), wcel(cv(hs1), universe), wa(wcel(cv(hs1), universe), wcel(cfv(c0, cv(hs1)), universe)))
  biantrud(wfn(c0, universe), wcel(cv(hs1), universe), wcel(cfv(c0, cv(hs1)), universe))
  fvexd(c0, cv(hs1), wfn(c0, universe))
  elrab(hs0, cv(hs1), universe, wcel(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), universe), wcel(cfv(c0, cv(hs1)), universe))
  eleq1d(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), universe, cfv(c0, cv(hs1)), wceq(cv(hs0), cv(hs1)))
  fveq2(cv(hs0), cv(hs1), c0)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(universe)
  diff.hs1.c(crab(hs0, universe, wcel(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), universe)))
  diff.hs1.c(universe)
  diff.hs1.w(wfn(c0, universe))
  diff.hs0.c(cv(hs1))
  diff.hs0.w(wcel(cfv(c0, cv(hs1)), universe))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm fncnvimaeqv(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0[Fn]𝕌 →(`' c0 " 𝕌)= 𝕌)
} = {
  eqtrd((`' c0 " 𝕌), universe, { hs0 ∈ 𝕌 |(c0 ` hs0)∈ 𝕌 }, c0[Fn]𝕌)
  fncnvima2(hs0, c0, universe, universe)
  eqrdv(hs1, { hs0 ∈ 𝕌 |(c0 ` hs0)∈ 𝕌 }, universe, c0[Fn]𝕌)
  syl6rbbr(c0[Fn]𝕌, hs1 ∈ { hs0 ∈ 𝕌 |(c0 ` hs0)∈ 𝕌 }, hs1 ∈ 𝕌, (hs1 ∈ 𝕌 ∧(c0 ` hs1)∈ 𝕌))
  biantrud(c0[Fn]𝕌, hs1 ∈ 𝕌, (c0 ` hs1)∈ 𝕌)
  fvexd(c0, hs1, c0[Fn]𝕌)
  elrab(hs0, hs1, universe, (c0 ` hs0)∈ 𝕌, (c0 ` hs1)∈ 𝕌)
  eleq1d((c0 ` hs0), universe, (c0 ` hs1), hs0 = hs1)
  fveq2(hs0, hs1, c0)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(universe)
  diff.hs1.c({ hs0 ∈ 𝕌 |(c0 ` hs0)∈ 𝕌 })
  diff.hs1.c(universe)
  diff.hs1.w(c0[Fn]𝕌)
  diff.hs0.c(hs1)
  diff.hs0.w((c0 ` hs1)∈ 𝕌)
}

blocks.name: bascnvimaeqv
blocks.content: The inverse image of the universal class ` _V ` under the base function is the universal class ` _V ` itself. (Proposed by Mario Carneiro, 7-Mar-2020.) (Contributed by AV, 7-Mar-2020.)

df-estrc
blocks.content: Definition of the category ExtStr of extensible structures. This is the category whose objects are all sets in a universe ` u ` regarded as extensible structures and whose morphisms are the functions between their base sets. If a set is not a real extensible structure, it is regarded as extensible structure with an empty base set. Because of ~ bascnvimaeqv we do not need to restrict the universe to sets which "have a base". Generally, we will take ` u ` to be a weak universe or Grothendieck universe, because these sets have closure properties as good as the real thing. (Proposed by Mario Carneiro, 5-Mar-2020.) (Contributed by AV, 7-Mar-2020.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-estrc(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5, setvar s6) {
  |- wceq(cestrc, cmpt(s0, universe, ctp(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), cv(s0)), cop(cfv(chom, cnx), cmpo(s1, s2, cv(s0), cv(s0), co(cfv(cbs, cv(s2)), cmap, cfv(cbs, cv(s1))))), cop(cfv(cco, cnx), cmpo(s3, s4, cxp(cv(s0), cv(s0)), cv(s0), cmpo(s5, s6, co(cfv(cbs, cv(s4)), cmap, cfv(cbs, cfv(c2nd, cv(s3)))), co(cfv(cbs, cfv(c2nd, cv(s3))), cmap, cfv(cbs, cfv(c1st, cv(s3)))), ccom(cv(s5), cv(s6))))))))
  -| diffss(s5, s6)
  -| diffss(s0, s6)
  -| diffss(s3, s6)
  -| diffss(s1, s6)
  -| diffss(s2, s6)
  -| diffss(s4, s6)
  -| diffss(s0, s5)
  -| diffss(s3, s5)
  -| diffss(s1, s5)
  -| diffss(s2, s5)
  -| diffss(s4, s5)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
}

axiom df-estrc(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5, setvar s6) {
  ⊢ ExtStrCat =(s0 ∈ 𝕌 ↦ { <(Base ` ndx), s0 >, <(Hom ` ndx),(s1 ∈ s0, s2 ∈ s0 ↦((Base ` s2)[↦](Base ` s1)))>, <(comp ` ndx),(s3 ∈(s0 × s0), s4 ∈ s0 ↦(s5 ∈((Base ` s4)[↦](Base `(2nd ` s3))), s6 ∈((Base `(2nd ` s3))[↦](Base `(1st ` s3)))↦(s5 ∘ s6)))> })
  ⊣ d(s5, s6)
  ⊣ d(s0, s6)
  ⊣ d(s3, s6)
  ⊣ d(s1, s6)
  ⊣ d(s2, s6)
  ⊣ d(s4, s6)
  ⊣ d(s0, s5)
  ⊣ d(s3, s5)
  ⊣ d(s1, s5)
  ⊣ d(s2, s5)
  ⊣ d(s4, s5)
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, s4)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)
  ⊣ d(s3, s4)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s4)
  ⊣ d(s2, s4)
}

thm estrcval(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, wff w0) {
  ⊢ (w0 → c0 = { <(Base ` ndx), c1 >, <(Hom ` ndx), c2 >, <(comp ` ndx), c3 > })
  ⊣ c0 =(ExtStrCat ` c1)

blocks.name: estrcbasbas
blocks.content: An element of the base set of the base set of the category of extensible structures (i.e. the base set of an extensible structure) belongs to the considered weak universe. (Contributed by AV, 22-Mar-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm estrcbasbas(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0) {
  |- wi(wa(w0, wcel(c0, c1)), wcel(cfv(cbs, c0), c2))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cestrc, c2))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cbs, c3))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cwun))
} = {
  imp(w0, wcel(c0, c1), wcel(cfv(cbs, c0), c2))
  sylbid(w0, wcel(c0, c1), wcel(cfv(cbs, c0), c2), wcel(c0, c2))
  eleq2d(c0, c1, c2, w0)
  syl6reqr(c1, c2, cfv(cbs, c3), w0)
  estrcbas(c2, c3, cwun, w0)
  syl(w0, wi(wcel(c0, c2), wcel(cfv(cbs, c0), c2)), wcel(c2, cwun))
  ex(wcel(c2, cwun), wcel(c0, c2), wcel(cfv(cbs, c0), c2))
  wunstr(cbs, c0, c2, nat1, wa(wcel(c2, cwun), wcel(c0, c2)))
  df-base()
  simpl(wcel(c2, cwun), wcel(c0, c2))
  simpr(wcel(c2, cwun), wcel(c0, c2))
}

blocks.name: estrcid
blocks.content: The identity arrow in the category of extensible structures is the identity function of base sets. (Contributed by AV, 8-Mar-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm estrcid(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wceq(cfv(c0, c1), cres(cid, cfv(cbs, c1))))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cestrc, c3))
  -| wceq(c0, cfv(ccid, c2))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, c4))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, c3))
} = {
  fvmptd(hs0, c0, c1, cres(cid, cfv(cbs, c1)), c3, cres(cid, cfv(cbs, cv(hs0))), universe, w0)
  syl5eq(c0, cmpt(hs0, c3, cres(cid, cfv(cbs, cv(hs0)))), cfv(ccid, c2), w0)
  simprd(w0, wceq(cfv(ccid, c2), cmpt(hs0, c3, cres(cid, cfv(cbs, cv(hs0))))), wcel(c2, ccat))
  syl(w0, wa(wcel(c2, ccat), wceq(cfv(ccid, c2), cmpt(hs0, c3, cres(cid, cfv(cbs, cv(hs0)))))), wcel(c3, c4))
  estrccatid(hs0, c3, c4, c2)
  adantl(w0, wceq(cv(hs0), c1), wceq(cres(cid, cfv(cbs, cv(hs0))), cres(cid, cfv(cbs, c1))))
  reseq2d(cid, cfv(cbs, cv(hs0)), cfv(cbs, c1), wceq(cv(hs0), c1))
  fveq2(cv(hs0), c1, cbs)
  resiexd(cfv(cbs, c1), universe, w0)
  fvexd(cbs, c1, w0)
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c(cres(cid, cfv(cbs, c1)))
  diff.hs0.c(c3)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
  diff.hs0.c(c4)
  diff.hs0.c(c2)
}

  ⊢ (w0 →(c0 ` c1)=(= |`(Base ` c1)))

  adantl(w0, hs0 = c1, (= |`(Base ` hs0))=(= |`(Base ` c1)))
  reseq2d(cid, (Base ` hs0), (Base ` c1), hs0 = c1)
  fveq2(hs0, c1, cbs)
  resiexd((Base ` c1), universe, w0)
  fvexd(cbs, c1, w0)
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c((= |`(Base ` c1)))
  diff.hs0.c(c3)
  diff.hs0.w(w0)
  diff.hs0.c(c4)
  diff.hs0.c(c2)

blocks.name: funcestrcsetc
blocks.content: The "natural forgetful functor" from the category of extensible structures into the category of sets which sends each extensible structure to its base set, preserving the morphisms as mappings between the corresponding base sets. (Contributed by AV, 23-Mar-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm funcestrcsetc(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wbr(c0, co(c1, cfunc, c2), c3))

  -| wceq(c6, cfv(cbs, c2))

  -| wi(w0, wceq(c0, cmpt(s0, c5, cfv(cbs, cv(s0)))))
  -| wi(w0, wceq(c3, cmpo(s0, s1, c5, c5, cres(cid, co(cfv(cbs, cv(s1)), cmap, cfv(cbs, cv(s0)))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c5)
  -| diffsc(s0, c6)
  -| diffsc(s1, c5)
  -| diffsw(s0, w0)
  -| diffsw(s1, w0)
} = {
  isfuncd(hs0, hs1, hs2, hs3, hs4, c0, c1, c2, c3, c5, c6, cfv(chom, c1), cfv(chom, c2), cfv(ccid, c1), cfv(ccid, c2), cfv(cco, c1), cfv(cco, c2), w0)

  syl(w0, wcel(c1, ccat), wcel(c4, cwun))
  estrccat(c4, cwun, c1)
  syl(w0, wcel(c2, ccat), wcel(c4, cwun))
  setccat(c4, cwun, c2)
  funcestrcsetclem3(s0, c0, c5, c6, c1, c4, c2, w0)

blocks.name: fthestrcsetc
blocks.content: The "natural forgetful functor" from the category of extensible structures into the category of sets which sends each extensible structure to its base set is faithful. (Contributed by AV, 2-Apr-2020.)

blocks.name: fullestrcsetc
blocks.content: The "natural forgetful functor" from the category of extensible structures into the category of sets which sends each extensible structure to its base set is full. (Contributed by AV, 2-Apr-2020.)

thm fullestrcsetc(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, wff w0) {

  ⊣ c1 =(ExtStrCat ` c4)
  ⊣ c2 =(SetCat ` c4)

  ⊣ (w0 → c0 =(s0 ∈ c5 ↦(Base ` s0)))
  ⊣ (w0 → c3 =(s0 ∈ c5, s1 ∈ c5 ↦(= |`((Base ` s1)[↦](Base ` s0)))))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c5)
  ⊣ d(s0, c6)
  ⊣ d(s1, c5)
  ⊣ d(s0, w0)
  ⊣ d(s1, w0)
} = {
  sylanbrc(w0, c0[(c1[Full]c2)]c3, c0[(c1[Func]c2)]c3, ∀(hs0 ∈ c5, ∀(hs1 ∈ c5,((hs0[c3]hs1):(hs0[(Hom ` c1)]hs1)↠((c0 ` hs0)[(Hom ` c2)](c0 ` hs1))))))
  funcestrcsetc(s0, s1, c0, c1, c2, c3, c4, c5, c6, w0)
  ralrimivva(hs0, hs1, c5, c5, w0, ((hs0[c3]hs1):(hs0[(Hom ` c1)]hs1)↠((c0 ` hs0)[(Hom ` c2)](c0 ` hs1))))
  sylanbrc((w0 ∧(hs0 ∈ c5 ∧ hs1 ∈ c5)), ((hs0[c3]hs1):(hs0[(Hom ` c1)]hs1)↠((c0 ` hs0)[(Hom ` c2)](c0 ` hs1))), ((hs0[c3]hs1):(hs0[(Hom ` c1)]hs1)→((c0 ` hs0)[(Hom ` c2)](c0 ` hs1))), ∀(hs2 ∈((c0 ` hs0)[(Hom ` c2)](c0 ` hs1)), ∃(hs3 ∈(hs0[(Hom ` c1)]hs1), hs2 =((hs0[c3]hs1)` hs3))))
  funcestrcsetclem8(s0, s1, hs0, c5, hs1, c3, c1, c0, c2, c4, c6, w0)
  ralrimiv(hs2, ((c0 ` hs0)[(Hom ` c2)](c0 ` hs1)), (w0 ∧(hs0 ∈ c5 ∧ hs1 ∈ c5)), ∃(hs3 ∈(hs0[(Hom ` c1)]hs1), hs2 =((hs0[c3]hs1)` hs3)))
  sylbid((w0 ∧(hs0 ∈ c5 ∧ hs1 ∈ c5)), hs2 ∈((c0 ` hs0)[(Hom ` c2)](c0 ` hs1)), ∃(hs3 ∈(hs0[(Hom ` c1)]hs1), hs2 =((hs0[c3]hs1)` hs3)), (hs2 :(Base ` hs0)→(Base ` hs1)))
  bitrd((w0 ∧(hs0 ∈ c5 ∧ hs1 ∈ c5)), hs2 ∈((c0 ` hs0)[(Hom ` c2)](c0 ` hs1)), (hs2 :(Base ` hs0)→(Base ` hs1)), (hs2 :(c0 ` hs0)→(c0 ` hs1)))
  elsetchom(hs2, (c0 ` hs0), (Hom ` c2), (c0 ` hs1), c2, c4, cwun, (w0 ∧(hs0 ∈ c5 ∧ hs1 ∈ c5)))
  adantrr(w0, hs0 ∈ c5, hs1 ∈ c5, (c0 ` hs0)∈ c4)
  funcestrcsetclem2(s0, hs0, c5, c0, c4, c1, c2, c6, w0)

blocks.name: equivestrcsetc
blocks.content: The "natural forgetful functor" from the category of extensible structures into the category of sets which sends each extensible structure to its base set is an equivalence. According to definition 3.33 (1) of [Adamek] p. 36, "A functor F : A -> B is called an _equivalence_ provided that it is full, faithful, and isomorphism-dense in the sense that for any B-object B' there exists some A-object A' such that F(A') is isomorphic to B'.". Therefore, the category of sets and the category of extensible structures are equivalent, according to definition 3.33 (2) of [Adamek] p. 36, "Categories A and B are called _equivalent_ provided that there is an equivalence from A to B.". (Contributed by AV, 2-Apr-2020.)

blocks.name: setc1strwun
blocks.content: A constructed one-slot structure with the objects of the category of sets as base set in a weak universe. (Contributed by AV, 27-Mar-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm setc1strwun(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0) {
  |- wi(wa(w0, wcel(c0, c1)), wcel(csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c0)), c2))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(csetc, c2))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cbs, c3))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cwun))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(com, c2))
} = {
  syldan(w0, wcel(c0, c1), wcel(csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c0)), c2), wcel(c0, c2))
  biimpa(w0, wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c0, c2))
  eleq2d(c0, c1, c2, w0)
  syl6reqr(c1, c2, cfv(cbs, c3), w0)
  setcbas(c2, c3, cwun, w0)
  1strwun(c0, c2, csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c0)), w0)
  eqid(csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c0)))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm setc1strwun(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0) {
  ⊢ ((w0 ∧ c0 ∈ c1)→ { <(Base ` ndx), c0 > } ∈ c2)
  ⊣ c3 =(SetCat ` c2)
  ⊣ c1 =(Base ` c3)
  ⊣ (w0 → c2 ∈ WUni)
  ⊣ (w0 → _om ∈ c2)
} = {
  syldan(w0, c0 ∈ c1, { <(Base ` ndx), c0 > } ∈ c2, c0 ∈ c2)
  biimpa(w0, c0 ∈ c1, c0 ∈ c2)
  eleq2d(c0, c1, c2, w0)
  syl6reqr(c1, c2, (Base ` c3), w0)
  setcbas(c2, c3, cwun, w0)
  1strwun(c0, c2, { <(Base ` ndx), c0 > }, w0)
  eqid({ <(Base ` ndx), c0 > })
}

  a1ii(wi(wa(w0, wcel(c0, c1)), wceq(cfv(c2, c0), csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c0)))), wceq(c1, cfv(cbs, c3)))
  fvmptd(s0, c2, c0, csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c0)), c1, csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), cv(s0))), universe, wa(w0, wcel(c0, c1)))
  adantr(w0, wcel(c0, c1), wceq(c2, cmpt(s0, c1, csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), cv(s0))))))
  adantl(wa(w0, wcel(c0, c1)), wceq(cv(s0), c0), wceq(csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), cv(s0))), csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c0))))
  sneqd(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), cv(s0)), cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c0), wceq(cv(s0), c0))
  opeq2(cv(s0), c0, cfv(cbs, cnx))
  simpr(w0, wcel(c0, c1))
  a1i(wa(w0, wcel(c0, c1)), wcel(csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c0)), universe))
  snex(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c0))

  ⊢ ((w0 ∧ c0 ∈ c1)→(c2 ` c0)= { <(Base ` ndx), c0 > })
  ⊣ c3 =(SetCat ` c4)
  ⊣ c1 =(Base ` c3)

} = {

  a1ii(((w0 ∧ c0 ∈ c1)→(c2 ` c0)= { <(Base ` ndx), c0 > }), c1 =(Base ` c3))
  fvmptd(s0, c2, c0, { <(Base ` ndx), c0 > }, c1, { <(Base ` ndx), s0 > }, universe, (w0 ∧ c0 ∈ c1))
  adantr(w0, c0 ∈ c1, c2 =(s0 ∈ c1 ↦ { <(Base ` ndx), s0 > }))
  adantl((w0 ∧ c0 ∈ c1), s0 = c0, { <(Base ` ndx), s0 > } = { <(Base ` ndx), c0 > })
  sneqd(<(Base ` ndx), s0 >, <(Base ` ndx), c0 >, s0 = c0)
  opeq2(s0, c0, (Base ` ndx))
  simpr(w0, c0 ∈ c1)

blocks.name: funcsetcestrc
blocks.content: The "embedding functor" from the category of sets into the category of extensible structures which sends each set to an extensible structure consisting of the base set slot only, preserving the morphisms as mappings between the corresponding base sets. (Contributed by AV, 28-Mar-2020.)

  ⊣ (w0 → c3 =(s0 ∈ c5, s1 ∈ c5 ↦(= |`(s1[↦]s0))))

blocks.name: fullsetcestrc
blocks.content: The "embedding functor" from the category of sets into the category of extensible structures which sends each set to an extensible structure consisting of the base set slot only is full. (Contributed by AV, 1-Apr-2020.)

  adantrr(w0, wcel(cv(hs0), c5), wcel(cv(hs1), c5), wcel(cfv(c0, cv(hs0)), c4))

  diff.hs1.c((Hom ` c2))
}

blocks.name: embedsetcestrc
blocks.content: The "embedding functor" from the category of sets into the category of extensible structures which sends each set to an extensible structure consisting of the base set slot only is an embedding. According to definition 3.27 (1) of [Adamek] p. 34, a functor "F is called an _embedding_ provided that F is injective on morphisms", or according to remark 3.28 (1) in [Adamek] p. 34, "a functor is an embedding if and only if it is faithful and injective on objects". (Contributed by AV, 31-Mar-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm embedsetcestrc(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wa(wbr(c0, co(c1, cfth, c2), c3), wf1(c0, c4, c5)))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(csetc, c6))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cbs, c1))
  -| wi(w0, wceq(c0, cmpt(s0, c4, csn(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), cv(s0))))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c6, cwun))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(com, c6))
  -| wi(w0, wceq(c3, cmpo(s0, s1, c4, c4, cres(cid, co(cv(s1), cmap, cv(s0))))))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cestrc, c6))
  -| wceq(c5, cfv(cbs, c2))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c4)
  -| diffsc(s0, c5)
  -| diffsc(s1, c4)
  -| diffsw(s0, w0)
  -| diffsw(s1, w0)
} = {
  jca(w0, wbr(c0, co(c1, cfth, c2), c3), wf1(c0, c4, c5))
  fthsetcestrc(s0, s1, c0, c1, c2, c3, c6, c4, w0)
  embedsetcestrclem(s0, c0, c4, c5, c1, c6, c2, w0)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm embedsetcestrc(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, wff w0) {
  ⊢ (w0 →(c0[(c1[Faith]c2)]c3 ∧(c0 : c4 ↣ c5)))
  ⊣ c1 =(SetCat ` c6)
  ⊣ c4 =(Base ` c1)
  ⊣ (w0 → c0 =(s0 ∈ c4 ↦ { <(Base ` ndx), s0 > }))
  ⊣ (w0 → c6 ∈ WUni)
  ⊣ (w0 → _om ∈ c6)
  ⊣ (w0 → c3 =(s0 ∈ c4, s1 ∈ c4 ↦(= |`(s1[↦]s0))))
  ⊣ c2 =(ExtStrCat ` c6)
  ⊣ c5 =(Base ` c2)
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c2)
  ⊣ d(s0, c4)
  ⊣ d(s0, c5)
  ⊣ d(s1, c4)
  ⊣ d(s0, w0)
  ⊣ d(s1, w0)
} = {
  jca(w0, c0[(c1[Faith]c2)]c3, (c0 : c4 ↣ c5))
  fthsetcestrc(s0, s1, c0, c1, c2, c3, c6, c4, w0)
  embedsetcestrclem(s0, c0, c4, c5, c1, c6, c2, w0)
}
